topic_rationale: Addison's disease is a rare, chronic endocrine disorder wherein the adrenal glands do not produce enough steroid hormones. It's an educational topic as it is potentially life-threatening and requires lifelong management.

explanations.tile_0: Hyperpigmentation in Addison's disease is due to high ACTH levels which also stimulate melanin production.
explanations.tile_1: Postural hypotension results from aldosterone deficiency leading to sodium loss, volume depletion, and hypotension.
explanations.tile_2: Hypoglycemia in Addison's disease occurs due to cortisol deficiency, impairing gluconeogenesis.
explanations.tile_3: Fatigue is a common symptom of Addison's disease due to the lack of cortisol.
explanations.tile_4: Hyponatremia is caused by aldosterone deficiency leading to impaired renal sodium reabsorption.
explanations.tile_5: Hyperkalemia occurs because of decreased aldosterone, leading to reduced renal potassium excretion.
explanations.tile_6: Low cortisol level is the main hormonal feature of Addison's disease due to adrenal insufficiency.
explanations.tile_7: High ACTH level is due to lack of negative feedback inhibition by cortisol.
explanations.tile_8: Absence or atrophy of adrenal glands on CT scan can be seen in Addison's disease.
